lesson.title: Kalman Filters
lesson.summary: Learn from the best! Sebastian Thrun will walk you through the usage and concepts of a Kalman Filter using Python.

question.prompt: Check the box where you would assume the object to be at t=4
Check the graphs that are gaussians.

atoms.title: Variance Comparison
atoms.instructor_notes: This question asks about the variance of each Gaussian (not its covariance). Correction: In the video under quiz page, it should be "x and u" at 00:15.

question.title: Variance Comparison
question.alt_text: Variance Comparison  f of x equals 1 over parentheses squareroot of 2 pi sigma squared parentheses closed. All of this is multiplied by exponent -Â½ multiplied by parenthesis x-mu parentheses closed squared over sigma squared.  There are three graphs, each that can be large, medium or small.   The first graph starts at (1,0) and ends at (7,0). It slopes upwards, hits a maximum point at about (4,5) and then slopes down again. The second graph starts at (0,0), has a sharp upward curve, hits a maximum point at about (3, 7) and quickly slopes down and ends at (5,0).  The third graph starts at (0,0), curves upwards at (3, 2) and curves downward until (8, 0).

widgets.label: This option for the first graph is large for the first graph.
This option for the first graph is medium for the first graph.
This option for the first graph is small for the first graph.
This option for the second graph is large for the second graph.
This option for the second graph is medium for the second graph.
This option for the second graph is small for the second graph.
This option for the third graph is large for the third graph.
This option for the third graph is medium for the third graph.
This option for the third graph is small for the third graph.
option2
option3
option4

question.title: Evaluate Gaussian
question.alt_text: Evaluate Gaussian   f of x equals 1 over parentheses squareroot of 2 pi sigma squared parentheses closed. All of this is multiplied by exponent -Â½ multiplied by parenthesis x-mu parentheses closed squared over sigma squared.  mu equals 10. sigma squared equals 4. x equals 8.  what is f of x?

widgets.label: Insert your numeric response in this box.

initial_code_files.text:
#For this problem, you aren't writing any code.
#Instead, please just change the last argument 
#in f() to maximize the output.

from math import *

def f(mu, sigma2, x):
    return 1/sqrt(2.*pi*sigma2) * exp(-.5*(x-mu)**2 / sigma2)

print f(10.,4.,8.) #Change the 8. to something else!
initial_code_files.name: studentMain.py

atoms.text:
The Kalman Filter represents our distributions by Gaussians and iterates on two main cycles.

Sebastian summarizes some of the key concepts from these cycles in the below referenced links. If you are interested, please feel free to check out these links directly from Sebastian's class on Artificial Intelligence for Robotics.

### The first cycle is the **Measurement Update**.

* Requires a [product](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/cs373/lessons/48739381/concepts/487235990923#) 
* Uses [Bayes rule](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/cs373/lessons/48739381/concepts/487221690923#).


### The second cycle is the **Motion Update**.

* Involves a convolution 
* Uses [total probability](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/cs373/lessons/48739381/concepts/486736290923#).

widgets.label: option2
option3
option4

question.title: Predicting the Peak
question.alt_text: The three options are in a straight, upwards line.

widgets.label: This option correlates with the mu (the mean of the prior) of the graph.
This option correlates with the mean of the graph.
This option correlates with the upper deviation of the graph.

question.title: Parameter Update
question.alt_text: Parameter Update  mu prime equals 1 over sigma squared plus r squared all multiplied by prantheses r squared mu plus sigma squared v prantheses closed.  The second equation is sima squared prime equals 1 over prantheses 1 over sigma squared parentheses closed added to 1 over t squared.  mu here equals 10.  v equals 12.  sigma squared equals 4.   t squared equals 4.

widgets.label: What is mu prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.
What is sigma squared prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.

question.title: Parameter Update 2
question.alt_text: Parameter Update 2  mu prime equals 1 over sigma squared plus r squared all multiplied by prantheses r squared mu plus sigma squared v prantheses closed.  The second equation is sima squared prime equals 1 over prantheses 1 over sigma squared parentheses closed added to 1 over t squared.  mu here equals 10.  v equals 13.  sigma squared equals 8.   t squared equals 2.

widgets.label: What is mu prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.
What is sigma squared prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.

question.title: Separated Gaussians
question.alt_text: Separated Gaussian   There are two graphs sitting at an unspecified distance from one another. Both have the same covariance. Where would the new mean be?

widgets.label: The first point is to the right of the first graph and is the closest to the first graph. Select this if you think this is the closest to the mean.
The second point is more to the right of the first point and in the middle of the two graphs. Select this if you think this is the closest to the mean.
The third point is more to the right of the second point and is the last point before the second graph. Select this if you think this is the closest to the mean.
The fourth point is at the end of the second graph. Select this if you think this is the closest to the mean.

atoms.title: Separated Gaussians 2
atoms.instructor_notes: Correction: Sebastian says "because both means are the same" at 0:24, it should be "because both **variances** are the same"

question.title: Separated Gaussians 2
question.alt_text: Separated Gaussians 2  There are two graphs sitting at an unspecified distance from one another. Both have the same covariance. Where would the new mean be?

widgets.label: The first point is to the right of the first graph and is the closest to the first graph. It is connected with a new graph that has a very sharp top point.
The second point is more to the right of the first point and in the middle of the two graphs. It is connected to a graph that has a smoother curve.
The third point is more to the right of the second point and is the last point before the second graph. It is connected to a graph with a very smooth, distributed graph.

initial_code_files.text:
# Write a program to update your mean and variance
# when given the mean and variance of your belief
# and the mean and variance of your measurement.
# This program will update the parameters of your
# belief function.

def update(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean =
    new_var =
    return [new_mean, new_var]

print update(10.,8.,13., 2.)

atoms.title: Gaussian Motion
atoms.instructor_notes: There is a typo in the formula. It should read ÏÂ²â² â ÏÂ² + rÂ².

question.title: Gaussian Motion
question.alt_text: Gaussian Motion  There are two graphs - a green one and a red one.  mu is 8. sigma squared is 4. u equals 10. r squared equals 6.

widgets.label: What is mu prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.
What is sigma squared prime equal to? Insert your numeric answer in this text box.

initial_code_files.text:
# Write a program that will predict your new mean
# and variance given the mean and variance of your 
# prior belief and the mean and variance of your 
# motion. 

def update(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean = (var2 * mean1 + var1 * mean2) / (var1 + var2)
    new_var = 1/(1/var1 + 1/var2)
    return [new_mean, new_var]

def predict(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean =
    new_var =
    return [new_mean, new_var]

print predict(10., 4., 12., 4.)
initial_code_files.name: studentMain.py

atoms.title: Kalman Filter Code
atoms.instructor_notes: Make sure to print out ONLY the final values of the mean and the variance in a list [mu, sig]. Do not print intermediate values as shown in the video.

initial_code_files.text:
# Write a program that will iteratively update and
# predict based on the location measurements 
# and inferred motions shown below. 

def update(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean = float(var2 * mean1 + var1 * mean2) / (var1 + var2)
    new_var = 1./(1./var1 + 1./var2)
    return [new_mean, new_var]

def predict(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean = mean1 + mean2
    new_var = var1 + var2
    return [new_mean, new_var]

measurements = [5., 6., 7., 9., 10.]
motion = [1., 1., 2., 1., 1.]
measurement_sig = 4.
motion_sig = 2.
mu = 0.
sig = 10000.

#Please print out ONLY the final values of the mean
#and the variance in a list [mu, sig]. 

# Insert code here

print [mu, sig]
initial_code_files.name: studentMain.py

question.title: Kalman Prediction
question.alt_text: Kalman Filters  There are four points in a nearly perfect diagonal line, sloping upwards from t=0 to t= 1 to t=2 to t=3. Your job is to find where t =4 would be from three points.  This is the first point. It continues the diagonal line.  This is the second point. It is not on the diagonal line but has a vertical component that is higher than t=3 and a horizontal component that is further left from the line.  This is the third point. It is not on the diagonal line but shares the vertical component almost equal to that of t = 2 and a horizontal component that is further left from the line.

widgets.label: Pick this if you think it is at t=2.
t=3 is the next point in the diagonal line. Pick this if you think it is t=3.
This is the next point in the diagonal line after t=3. Pick if you think this is the solution.

question.title: Kalman Filter Prediction
question.alt_text: Kalman Filter Prediction  There is a line graph showing points 1, 2, 3 and 4. t =1 is over 1. t =2 is over 2. t =3 is over 3. 4 is circled.  âPredictionâ is a graph with 1 through 4 on the x axis and -1 to 2 on the y axis.  There is a line through x = 1.   You have to select from one of three points - (1, 1), (2, 0) and (2, 1).

widgets.label: This is (1,1).
This is (2,0).
This is (2,1).

question.title: Another Prediction
question.alt_text: Another Prediction  There is a line graph showing points 1, 2, 3 and 4. t =1 is over 1. t =2 is over 2. t =3 is over 3. 4 is circled.  âPredictionâ is a graph with 1 through 4 on the x axis and -1 to 2 on the y axis.  There is a line through x = 1.   You have to select from one of the six points - (2, 1) and (2, 2) and (3, 1) and (3, 2) and (4, 1) and (4, 2).

widgets.label: This is point (2, 1).
This is point (2, 2).
This is point (3, 1).
This is point (3, 2).
This is point (4, 1).
This is point (4, 2).

atoms.title: More Kalman Filters
atoms.instructor_notes:
There is an error in this video in the discussion between 1:52 and 2:10. The new predicted Gaussians should lie on the horizontal line x_dot = 1 instead of the diagonal line as they are drawn in the video. The reason for this is that we are assuming a model of constant velocity instead of acceleration.

In addition, the formula ```x' = x + áº``` shown a 2:30 should include a multiplication by time units: ```x' = x + Îtáº'```

atoms.title: Kalman Filter Design
atoms.instructor_notes:
The assignment

    x_prime = x + x_dot

assumes that the time interval delta_t is equal to 1. A more general formula is

    x_prime = x + x_dot*delta_t
